Travolta is more interesting, and everytime they cut away from Travolta to Meyers, you're like, "Hey! Hey! No! You get back to Travolta! We don't want to see your face anymore!" Personally, I would have given the script a rewrite, write Jonathan Rhys Meyers out, and give his translation skills to Travolta. reviewText: FROM PARIS WITH LOVE is an odd title for this 93 minutes of slaughtering in the name of smoking out Terrorists.  But then it is an odd movie, too, one that fans of John Travolta's screen chewing side will love.  There is so little story that it doesn't need summary.  Two guys - one Special OPs wannabe James Reece (Jonathan Rhys Meyers with an American accent) is assigned to partner with an infamous spy called Charlie Wax (John Travolta in top edgy comedic form) to first uncover a cocaine ring of Chinese (they accomplish this by killing everyone) and then the two jump around on buildings and stairwells and car chases and explosions to uncover planned terrorist attack from the Pakistanis - again accomplished by killing everyone.  There is a bit of twist in the relationship of Reece and his beautiful girlfriend Caroline (Kasia Smutniak) that adds a bit of story to the otherwise bullet-infested goings-on, but best that be not revealed as it is the only part of the film that resembles story.The reason this creation by writers Luc Beeson and Adi Hasak works in the hands of director Pierre Morel lies completely in the entertainment provided by Travolta - and the straight guy image of Rhys Meyers.  Their banter does little to make us get into the characters, but they do provide a vaudeville-like dance with weapons peppered with some funny set-ups and dialog to make this movie entertaining.  At least everyone appreciates the purpose of making the movie is not a serious one and watching it can be a fairly good evening's past time.  Grady Harp, June 10

reviewText: FROM PARIS WITH LOVE, hard-boiled and audacious and kinetic and pretty damn vulgar, welcomes you to the theater of the unexpected. This is one of them flicks in which you cannot make assumptions, because the plot will certainly throw you a curve and, in fact, several curves. Do come in, however, with the expectation of thrills and explosive action. And a seriously wired performance from John Travolta. Luc Besson co-wrote and co-produced this thing, so you know merde's gonna blow up.Paris, hotbed of l'amour and haute couture and also of perilous cloak and daggery stuff. By day James Reece (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) is the methodical personal aide to the U.S. Ambassador to France. On the surface, Reece seems a settled guy, with a steady career, a gorgeous girlfriend (Kasia Smutniak). But there's an itch he needs to scratch. And so James Reece also moonlights as a CIA man-of-action. Or, more accurately, as a CIA gofer. Reece has accomplished these namby-pamby errands for the CIA, and now he's craving real espionage missions. But is he ready for the unorthodox and borderline psychopathic partner the Agency assigns him? Special Agent Charlie Wax is the very definition of loose cannon. But maybe there's a method to his madness? Maybe so. Maybe no?From the moment Reece frees Charlie Wax from being detained at Orly airport, his world gets violently topsy-turvied. For the next few hours, Charlie Wax maniacally escorts Reece thru Paris' seedy underbelly. Wax isn't shy about applying force to follow his leads. He does this gleefully. And because it's John Travolta, you relish what he's doing on screen. Travolta brings flair and edginess to his role, and it helps that he's sporting a shaven pate and a mean goatee. Heck, he even gives a nod to that flick what revitalized his career in 1994. Here, he channels the ferocity of Denzel Washington in TRAINING DAY. You're never quite sure on which side of the law Charlie Wax really stands. His rookie partner, James Reece, is floored and flabbergasted by Wax's enigmatic actions. Jonathan Rhys Meyers, who himself can chew scenery, sits back and allows Travolta the spotlight. They make good foils for each other.FROM PARIS WITH LOVE charges along like a runaway train. It exudes so much attitude it should be snapping its fingers and sending out for a bag of chips. The plot is fairly labyrinthine. The twists are unexpected. The pace is frenzied and doesn't allow you a moment's breath. The action is explosive, with Travolta proving himself well-versed in sudden violence and general rough and tumble badassery. It's nice to see our main man with his swagger intact and delivering so righteously. So, yeah, see this one.

reviewText: While there is no shortage of people jockeying for position in line to condemn Luc Besson, there's no denying the entertainment of his action movies. Over the past ten years the man has given us Kiss of the Dragon, the Transporter franchise, and Taken. These movies will never be up for any major awards but they are still worth the money and time for action fans.Jonathan Rhys-Meyers plays James Reese, the personal assistant to the American Ambassador in France who does odd, low-level covert jobs on the side. He longs for the big leagues, and gets his wish (to the extreme) when he's suddenly partnered with the flamboyant Charlie Wax (an OTT John Travolta, who really seems to be enjoying himself). Wax has a mission in Paris, but he's keeping the full details from Reese, gradually letting him further into the tangle of twists as the elaborate story unfolds. Racking up a body count of more than one an hour in the process.The Travolta/Meyers double-act mostly pays off, but, like Reese, the audience is left out in the cold for the duration. Meyers doesn't do much but stand aside while Travolta rampages through posses of bad guys. I know he's the 'everyman' we can identify with, thus giving us a smoother insight into the world of espionage, but if he was just given a tiny bit more to do than stand around wide-eyed and frightened the film would have gotten a higher rating from me.As 90-minute fluff we're talking serious entertainment here. If you're wanting more profound film-making look elsewhere (not that Besson is incapable of this either). From Paris With Love doesn't rewrite the rules of the action or spy genre, but it does play every expected note loudly and maniacally. Exactly how many films have a bald, goatee-sporting John Travolta hanging out of a car window talking on the phone in one hand with a giant mofo rocket-launcher in the other?The Blu Ray features a great 2.35:1 1080p picture with DTS HD-MA sound. reviewText: In this completely entertaining action thriller, lowly agent James Reece (Jonathan Rhys Meyers) gets paired up with wild-man, renegade, take no prisoners Charlie Wax (Travolta).  Initially they go after some small-time drug dealers and pimps, but eventually they move on to bigger, global-threat-level targets.  Wax cleans the floor with all of them (forgive me) in a rollercoaster of throat punches, double-taps, improvised explosives, and high-speed motorway rocket attacks.  Safety and holster your sidearm - Travolta doesn't need any help.The buddy action flick where a straight-laced partner teams with an unorthodox risk-taker is nothing new - Riggs are Murtagh they ain't - but the combination of Travolta and Meyers still has a good chemistry to it.  Travolta truly delivers in this one, mixing the slick talking and cool from Vince Vega inPulp Fiction(even a respectful, tongue-in-cheek nod to his Royale with Cheese line) with the omnipotent, kill everything that walks vibe of Gabriel Shear inSwordfish.  Seeing him disfigure gangsters with mere flicks of the wrist and decorate the countryside with corpses provides enough inspiration to join the UFC and the NRA the day after viewing.  Meyers plays his Robin to Travolta's Batman very well.  After his initial status as somewhat of a bumbling Magoo, he quickly transforms into Wax's protégé, culminating in a hard learned lesson that executing an enemy is sometimes the only choice.  The only problem is Meyers' effeminate appearance doesn't fit perfectly into the crash-bang-kill guy movie mold.  (It's OK, because Travolta excretes machismo in this one)It should come as no surprise that this 15-round slugfest was directed by Pierre Morel.  After directingDeath Wish Neeson, he was immediately dead-center on my "look out for this director"-radar; but now with one other arrow in his quiver - regardless of box office receipts - he has moved into the upper echelon of action directors.  Cinematography from Michel Abramowicz is top-notch.  Big surprise, he worked with Morel on Taken.  The angles selected make the action jump off the screen, and even give the impression that John Travolta is actually dishing out the beatings (which he isn't).This is guy movie.  An action film that has less twist than a pretzel, but moves so fast it doesn't even show up on radar, From Paris with Love is exciting and enjoyable on the same level as films likeDeath Race,Doomsday, and Death Wish Neeson.  Sit back and enjoy the carnage.Jason Elin

reviewText: James Reece (Jonathan Rhys Meyersis a low-level American diplomat serving in Paris, who is even lower down the totem pole as a CIA operative.  When you see him try to plant a bug in the office of French minister you get some idea why, but Reece aspires to be much more as he lives his cozy life with his French girl friend, Caroline (Kasia Smutniak).  Then Reece is assigned to be "partnered" (i.e., chauffer), Charlie Wax (John Travolta), around Paris while he completes his mission.  Wax is being held up at customs when Reece arrives and it quickly becomes clear that Wax is a rather volitile individual, who is likely to go off at any minute and in any direction.  As for Reece, there is reason to believe that despite his inexperience he might not be a total idiot and he may indeed earn a promotion, provided Wax does not get him killed before the credits role.  Anyhow, Wax is on a mission and Reece has to keep up orTravolta certainly relishes his role.  Sporting a shaved head and goatee, he is in fine form going over the top time and time again, because that is what the role demands.  The casting of Rhys Meyers was more problematic for me, because I have been watching him play Henry VIII for four seasons of "The Tudors," and I had a hard time with him playing Reece.  The character has to be clueless one moment and competent the next, and the actor seems so competent that the clueless parts do not play as well.  If this were Rhys Meyers' first major film role, then he might have a better chance of pulling it off.  Otherwise, if they are not going to recast the role, then the script needed to be tweaked so that it better suited him.  As for the violence and mayhem, the bits were Wax shows he is several steps ahead were more effective and impressive than the pure action sequences (there was one point where I started talking outloud to fire the damn rocket because Wax was passing up obvious shots to build the dramatic tension).  As for the mission, so much of that is in the background and obscurred by Wax's antics that when it comes time to get down to brass tacks and save the day, it comes across as rather anticlimatic."From Paris With Love" was directed by Pierre Morel, who also directed "Taken."  The latter is a action-thriller starring Liam Neesom while the former is an action-comedy with John Travolta.  "From Paris With Love" has a screenplay by Adi Hasak based on a story by Luc Besson, while "Taken" was written by both Besson and Robert Mark Kamen.  I ennumerate all of this because I am trying to figure out why "Taken" is so much the better film.  The title is apparently a take off on "From Russia With Love," although why anybody would want to invite comparisons between this movie and the James Bond franchise escapes me.  Travolta is certainly in fine form, wearing a goatee to go along with his shaved head, and going over the top again and again because that is what the role demands, so maybe the problem is that this film is unable to walk the line as an action-comedy.  Besson wants the film to end up being a series, but I cannot believe that is going to happen, and not just because this movie did not do that well as the boxoffice.  The relationship between the two main characters does not come across as being worth pursuing.  Is it Batman finding Robin?  I have to think Wax has a low threshold for mentoring others.  It certainly is not Danny Murtaugh pairing up with Martin Riggs, because it is hard to see Reece as the ying to Wax's yang.  So my bet is that this is a one and done "franchise."

reviewText: Pierre Morel proves once again that he is an action director that others would be hard pressed to beat. With his initial directorial effort DISTRICT 13 he showed how the ballet like sport of parkour could yield something new to the genre. TAKEN showed that you could have an older than usual central tough guy (Liam Neeson) who could take on all comers. And now he adds a twist to the buddy guy action flick genre and does it well.Jonathan Rhys Myers stars as James Reese, a mid level bureaucrat attached to the ambassador in France. He's the go to guy to make sure that things get done pronto. At the same time, he longs to be involved in the spy game, doing work on the down low for a mysterious voice on the phone. But it's all small things like changing plates on cars in the parking lot. Until his latest assignment.Reese gets a call one night telling him to pick up a special agent, his new partner, at the airport where he's being held by customs. Enter Charlie Wax (John Travolta). Charlie seems to be the obnoxious American, slamming the French and attempting to bully his way through. Reese comes to his aid and the pair set off. It turns out the behavior was a charade, Wax' way of getting his gun past customs.But the night is young and this IS Paris. Wax has Reese take him to a Chinese restaurant where suddenly after dinner he accost the waiter which results in over a dozen machine gun toting staff members to come out gun blazing. Once taken care of, Wax coaxes the waiter into showing him where the group was hiding cocaine.The night continues as the duo follow this same waiter to the big man in charge which results in more gunplay, this time in a circular stairwell and a mannequin factory. Yes, this movie uses more ammunition than a police firing range on test day.Through it all Reese wonders just how crazy his partner is. And just what is going on that result in the multiple shootouts he finds himself in. First Wax tells him it involves the daughter of the Secretary of State who got into drugs. But in the end we find out that instead he's trying to find a terrorist cell that smuggles drugs as a way to fund their operation. The group is planning something big but you don't know what it is until the final portion of the film.The movie, much like the explanations Reese gets, starts one way and ends another. All the elements of the comedic buddy film play between these two characters, the up tight button down guy who dreams of action and the play it as it comes deal with reality kill people left and right guy who takes things as they come. If you're in a tight jam, believe me you'll want the second guy at your side.But Reese' character changes, matures as he moves through the film though. Where he once thought it important to report in to his beautiful French girlfriend, he soon comes to realize there are more important things at stake. Like staying alive to get home to her. And the darker world of espionage comes to play in the latter half of the film, making it a touch more realistic than the usual buddy film.Through it all the action is non-stop. If you thought TAKEN delivered a body count that seemed high you ain't seen nothing. Bodies fall like crazy here and no one ever seems to question anyone involved in shooting them. And just as one scene finishes, another starts, the rest period between them lasting mere minutes. This film moves at an unrelenting pace that never gives you a chance to be bored.Both lead actors turn in fantastic performances. Rhys Myers is great as the wanna be spy who learns what being one really means. And Travolta has a chance to play a character unlike any he's done before, an over the top killer on a mission for the good guys who's willing to do anything to get the job done.If you're looking for something a little sedate or the old fashioned James Bond type spy flick that deals with tuxedos and martinis then this film isn't for you. If you're looking for a spy who downs energy drinks and thinks nothing of shooting the next person through the door with an air of certainty that it has to be a bad guy, then you'll love this film. For me it was tons of fun and a movie I know I'll watch more than once.

reviewText: Throughout a significant portion of "From Paris With Love", the new film from producer Luc Besson and director Pierre Morel ("Taken"), James Reece (Jonathan Rhys-Meyers), an American Embassy Assistant eager to become a CIA operative saddled with the duty of carrying around a large Chinese vase filled with cocaine. His partner and boss, Charlie Wax (John Travolta) entrusts the vase to him and wants the younger man to have it available at all times, it could be important, even as they run through tenement buildings and fight off various people with guns. My companion and I determined the reason Rhys Meyers was carrying this around was to inhibit him and allow Travolta, the older star, to have the opportunity to use martial arts, weapons and his fists, to make Travolta seem more athletic, agile and lithe. This is only the first of many problems with "Paris".Let's face it; Luc Besson's films have never placed a priority on narrative and character development. He writes and produces the French equivalent of a bad Joel Silver action films. Take a couple of disparate stars, give them improbable occupations and place them in unbelievable situations all in an effort to get them in the middle of increasingly preposterous action sequences. I have mentioned on more than one occasion that I tend to see a lot of these films. For every two or three that just don't work, Silver occasionally uses a group of people who help create a memorable, fun film. For every "Lethal Weapon" and "Die Hard", there are two or three "Fair Games" (Cindy Crawford and Billy Baldwin), two or three "Cradle 2 The Graves" (Jet Li and Romeo) and worse. Besson is exactly the same. It seems as though for every "Taken", we will have to wade through films like "From Paris With Love"."Taken" is not all that different from "Paris". Both films depict a fast-paced 'mission' hardened men take in the City of Lights. As they careen through the city, an impossible number of bullets fly, cars crash, and people die. But "Taken" has a key element that helps make that particular film work, making it more successful. That element is Liam Neeson. He seems like an odd choice for such a film; until you look at the fact he has appeared in a number of big budget Hollywood films alongside the smaller, more dramatic turns he has also done. "Taken" tells the story of a father who learns his daughter has been kidnapped while on vacation in Paris. He immediately resurrects his shadowy past (he did some sort of government work, work that is never completely identified) and chases her trail, ruthlessly killing most of the people who get in his way. The story is just this side of unbelievable and the action is over the top. What saves the film is Neeson's performance; he is so serious and grave throughout the film, we come to believe his character is on a real quest to save his daughter. His performance tips the scales and makes the film more believable, more interesting and more memorable.It even helps us overcome the scene in which his 18-year-old daughter (Maggie Grace, TV's "Lost") gets a pony for her birthday.In "From Paris With Love", the filmmakers have taken the same bare structure of their previous hit and mucked it up something fierce. Travolta is usually pretty good as the off-kilter psycho ("Face/Off"), the man who doesn't really care what happens and this only serves to make him more uninhibited, willing and able to do anything to accomplish his goals. In "Paris", he plays Charlie Wax, a bald headed man with a dark goatee who causes trouble for James at every turn. James is summoned to the airport to help get Charlie out of customs; Charlie insists he be allowed into the country with a number of cans of his favorite energy drink. As soon as James arrives, he realizes Charlie is crazy and this is problematic because this is our first impression as well. The only place for his character to go from there is become more realistic. Let me rephrase that. The only place for his character to go from there, and become more believable, is to become more realistic. But Charlie is the type of guy who shoots first and asks questions later. He never becomes more believable because he continues to do unbelievable things. As he becomes more cartoonish, the film quickly falls apart and we start to get bored. When the audience gets bored, it almost seems like all of the other problems jump off the screen, vying for our attention.One of the few moments that work is a scene following James as he struggles, he's carrying that huge vase, remember, up a spiral staircase in a Paris apartment building, trying to keep up with his boss. A couple of flights below his mentor, bodies begin to rain down and James has to weave his way through the human debris.Jonathan Rhys Meyers plays James Reece, the American Embassy assistant who does freelance work for the CIA. He seems to really, really want to be an operative for the CIA and gets his instructions from a faceless voice on his cell phone.A couple of times, he almost seems to wink at the camera. Look at this, it's going to be great. But this type of light-hearted tone, doesn't mesh with the body count and the violent story throughout the rest of the film.Reece lives with his longtime girlfriend, Caroline (Kasia Smutniak) and his face lights up every time he comes home to her. They are very much in love and both prone to trying to outdo each other in romantic gestures. One night, she proposes to him, because he never will and gives him a ring that once belonged to her father."Paris" has a story, but it seems vague and unimportant, something about a possible terrorist attack. I say it seems unimportant because it takes forever for Charlie to even reveal this little bit of information to his partner James. And when this is revealed, we begin to question the need or importance of the Chinese vase filled with cocaine. By keeping James in the dark, he manages to keep the viewer in the dark. The story isn't important to the filmmakers, they simply want to get Travolta and Rhys Meyers together and lead them through one action scene after another. This is the only point for the whole film, to create a bunch of situations for Travolta and his partner to shoot, fight, kill their way out of.It is also a little shocking to see the sheer number of foreigners killed in this film. With the exception of maybe a small handful of people, everyone the duo kills is Chinese, Pakistani, Black or of some other undetermined foreign origin. In "Taken", Neeson's character plowed his way through similar communities of immigrants in his search for his daughter. In "Paris", I really can't remember anyone killed who was identified as French or American. Is Besson trying to tell us something? Either he wants to paint Paris as a melting pot of people from many diverse backgrounds or he wants to show the state of his beautiful city. Whichever is true is impossible for me to say for sure, but I have my suspicions."From Paris With Love" is a film filled with impossible action, an inconsequential story and impressive overacting. It is a film impossible to love.

reviewText: Movie - 4.5From director Pierre Morel and the long line of all things related to Luc Besson comes, what I feel is, a very underrated action fest that oozes machismo, gritty style, and just enough wit for a very fun, if not mad, experience like only Monsieur Besson and his protégés can create. If anything, From Paris with Love is another great addition to the more recent over-the-top and B-movie-esque action titles like Shoot 'Em Up, Crank, and the Transporter movies. The plot doesn't scream "epic" or "highly emotional/intellectual narrative" by any means, as one might expect. But in terms of characters, dialogue, and gunplay, the film surely brings the goods to the table in each of these aspects thanks in big part to a sharp script penned by Besson himself, competent direction by Morel, and some especially fine performances by John Travolta and Jonathan Rhys Meyers. In particular, I really enjoyed some of the homages made throughout like the movie's title itself, "wax on, wax off," "Royale with cheese," BMW and Audi references to the Transporter series, and John Woo bullet ballet. Obviously, these won't earn points for any kind of originality, but that's part of the unique charm I've always liked about this genre. The only kind of value I could inform you of in preparation for this movie is to expect lots of guns, some flashy fisticuffs, an extremely well-choreographed car chase at the end, and a dark kind of buddy comedy. If any of you have seen Pulp Fiction, Face/Off, or even the remake of The Taking of Pelham 123, what you saw in Travolta with those movies is essentially the same kind of madman you get here, only he's a good guy. I love this kind of in-your-face anti-hero type of character, and after seeing him in Pelham most recently and now Paris, I have to say I don't think I've ever liked him more. Kudos to Morel and the ever-great Besson for this outstanding Euro action flick.Video - 4.5The director of photography for this film is Michel Abramowicz, who worked with Morel in Taken. Much like their last collaboration, From Paris with Love presents itself with a similar fashion. Colors aren't all that vibrant, even through the scenic shots of Paris during the opening credits. Morel admitted he wanted to go for a darker, grittier look, not so much to the level of grime and "dirt" akin to Taken, but something down-to-earth and representative of what he feels is Paris in his eyes. With that said, the color palette lends itself well to grays, blacks, and other dark hues, and even some occasional shades of red here and there. A very fine layer of grain also adds to the grittiness of the film, which at times does tend to interfere with image detail, though not very much. Contrast is excellent revealing a good deal of Travolta's bald head and Meyers fuzzy mustache, and black levels stay consistent with no signs of crush, aside for maybe one second in the scene where Travolta shoots the ceiling of the Chinese restaurant (some weird bit of editing or lighting perhaps?). But other than that, the transfer looks quite good.Audio - 5.0I don't have too many Lionsgate titles on BD, so when I do find a movie of theirs I actually like, I'm glad to know it'll at least sport another 7.1 DTS-HD track. And with that said, this movie presents itself with a full array of sound that really keeps all 8 channels working. Dialogue is clear and audible from the center, with a majority of the sound effects jumping around through the fronts, sides, and occasionally the rears. Gunshots, ricochets, glass breakage, and drywall penetration make up a good deal of the sound field and offer a very commendable effort with plenty of separation. High and low ends are especially handled well in the variations of guns being fired. The score by David Buckley also does a good job immersing the viewer in music when bullets aren't flying everywhere, helping to maintain the pace of the film. And LFEs, while not as frequent as I would've liked, are still flawless for when they're present, particularly at the end of the car chase sequence.Extras - 3.5The P-i-P commentary with Pierre Morel is a bit on the uninspired side, not so much for his fervor, as he really does like the result. But he never really goes in-depth with any of the major elements like the characters, production, or writing. Thankfully, though, the 26-minute making-of feature actually explains a lot of this more thoroughly, so if you're looking for the bulk of behind the scenes stuff, I recommend you just give that a look. Also included is a 16-minute featurette of being a spy, or at least the kind Meyers plays in this movie, from the perspectives and interviews of a handful of former CIA operatives. It starts off a little slow, but gets a bit more interesting when they compare and contrast real-world situations to the ones in the film. I found it pretty entertaining, if not oddly informative considering they were being pretty serious about it. There's also a little skit on the National Spy Museum, which sounded really awkward with the movie trailer guy voice narrating...Overall - 4.5I never got around to seeing this in theaters, though I'll admit I'm very surprised at how much I ended up liking this film. The plot and narrative aren't nearly as engrossing as Taken, but the violence, gunplay, chase sequence, and extremely likable character of John Travolta make this an equally entertaining alternative. It's a short film with good guys killing the bad guys and no BS in-between, and it certainly looks and sounds excellent with a good set of extras presented by Lionsgate. My mom never even heard of the movie and thought it was a romance title based on the name. Boy, was she glad she was wrong. Highly recommended for action junkies and fans of Travolta's "madman" act.

reviewText: You may not remember the name of Pierre Morel, but perhaps you may have seen the 2008 action-packed thriller "Taken". Yes, Pierre Morel was the director of the surprise hit starring intense Liam Neeson as vengeful father. "From Paris with Love" is from the same director, equally fast and furious, but somehow it lacks something that made his previous effort pretty entertaining: the characters we root for.I was not impressed partly because of the weak story (provided by Luc Besson). In "From Paris with Love" Jonathan Rhys Meyers plays James Reece, competent personal aide to the U.S. Ambassador in France. Young and smart James is obviously living a nice life, with a beautiful girlfriend Caroline (Kasia Smutniak), but he really wants to be a secret agent. Not a totally terrible setting for an action film, but still is too weak and dull to grab our attention.Things get interesting when an agent named Charlie Wax played by John Travolta arrives with a secret mission to accomplish in Paris. James is given an assignment to help this trigger-happy agent as a partner, but Charlie Wax's methods are far from conventional, often illegal. Actually he knows what he is doing, and in most cases his judgment is sound, but James and audiences are allowed to know that only after a massive shootout.Part buddy-buddy movie "From Paris with Love" begins with a fairly light-hearted action (with a nod to the star's "Vincent Vega" character), but it quickly loses momentum at the half-way mark after these two main characters, while we don't know much about them, are made to act separately. Also, in the second half the film takes itself too seriously, leaving a nasty taste in some of viewers' mouth.As seen in his previous films (including much better "District 13"), Pierre Morel knows how to shoot action scenes. Though greatly helped by editing and stunt persons, actions are competent. The problem is, as we don't know much about the characters, we don't know why these actions are taking place.

reviewText: Travolta MAKES this movie work as an absolute WILD RIDE & I LOVED IT!! Too many spy thrillers and even action flicks get so hung up on "the story" nowadays that you end up missing out on most of the FUN and just going, "Huh???" in the end (e.g. the first Mission Impossible). But don't worry...Except for an anemic first 15 minutes that seemed like it would never end, this movie doesn't simply stop periodically and try and TELL a story. Instead, the convoluted - but interesting - story DEVELOPS as the movie just shifts into high-gear and keeps moving at break-neck speed with jaw-dropping action alternating with over-the-top humor! It works so well because Travolta plays an off-the-chain near super hero spy with Jonathan Rhys Meyers playing the "straight guy" who also happens to be the wannabe super spy. And become a super spy he does - on Travolta's Fast Track Plan!!There's bodies piling up by the dozens wherever these guys go, a car chase that rivals anything you've ever seen in The Transporter series and gunfights/explosions galore. The tongue-in-cheek humor prevalent throughout the film shows that it never takes itself too seriously. For example, in one scene, Travolta tells his partner to stay a floor down while he goes up a spiral staircase after the bad guys. Every few seconds you hear a couple of muffled silencer shots and the bad guys literally start falling from the sky! Just brilliant and hilarious film-making!! Now, don't laugh too hard...But From Paris With Love reminds me quite a bit of Live Free or Die Hard. There are more than a few similarities: super hero-type playing off an inexperienced newbie; a bald Travolta and a bald Bruce Willis; both duos hunt down terrorists; special effects that look both real and unreal at the same time. But unlike Willis and his ever-present bloody shirt, Travolta's character never gets a scratch. I'm also impressed that he did so many of the stunts in this flick and didn't end up in the hospital! He moves around pretty well for a guy his age...There's a Special Feature on the DVD where former real spies claim there really are Special Ops guys like Travolta's character in the real world! Too bad there isn't a reality show that follows them around...In fact, this is EXACTLY the kind of movie I wish someone would turn into a weekly TV series! I'd watch it every week...
summary: A Bald Travolta Is Just the Beginning!
